author: justpassingthrou14
text:
yeah, that's just it. they don't say it "prevents" the transmission, just that it shows a "protective effect". And what that means is that they've shown NO causality, nor have they put forward a hypothetical method for any causality to work. And they base the statements regarding AIDS on a few VERY flawed studies conducted in sub-saharan africa, so in addition to being not relevant to the USA in terms of disease prevalance, nor in terms of the culture in which circumcision would be "used", they ALSO did some things that absolutely exaggerated the effect, to the point that those things could BE the ENTIRE effect.

So that's just it. It's dishonesty. Plain and simple. They want parents to control their kids' penises, and they don't care how much they have to lie to do it, or how many bad-faith arguments they have to put forward.

I've actually come up with a way to tell if someone *actually, in good faith* thinks that circumcision is not harmful, and that it is appropriate to do to an infant, in the way that it is done in the USA.

It's simple. Any man that wants his son circumcised must do the following.  1) get his own penis cut on (if he was previously circumcised, then remove just a little more tissue- but if he wasn't, then do a full circumcision anyway), with the same amount of anesthesia that we give to infants- that is, almost none. It has to be done with the adult fully awake and strapped to the operating table. And he cannot revoke consent- once he's strapped down, he's getting cut. The same can be done to a woman, with appropriate changes to what amount of the clitoris gets removed (the foreskin has about half the nerve endings of the penis, so about 2/3 of the clitoris sounds about right).

Step 2). wait 6 months for it to heal. During that time, if the person experiences any pain, the doctor cannot treat it. However if the symptoms are plainly visible, such that a parent would notice them on a fussy baby during a diaper change, THEN the guy can go to the doctor. But he can't speak while at the doctor's. This can be enforced any number of ways.

Step 3). you'd think here it would be okay for the person to say "okay, I think that's okay to do to my son". But you'd be wrong. The person who was just cut is only NOW informed about what the procedure may entail. So NOW he can give informed consent. But if we let him just have it done to the baby, he could be simply saying "okay, I endured the pain, now he can, too." And that's not ethical. It's the OPPOSITE of ethical. To do that would be SUBJECTING the baby to something, rather than choosing it because the father has decided that the costs are not too high. The dad has to choose to have his own penis cut on AGAIN, the same as before, strapped down with no ability to stop the process, and without anesthetic, while fully awake, now that he knows what it entails and exactly how bad it will hurt.

Step 4) wait another 6 months, with the same restrictions- he's not allowed to seek a doctor regarding his penis unless the problem is visible to an untrained eye, and then, he cannot speak during the doctor's appointment.

After that, this person has demonstrated that he fully understands what it means to make the decision to alter someone else's genitals without consent. And he can then request a surgeon to do the circumcision.

Also, any doctor who will be cutting on an infant's penis without medical need would be required to go through this in exactly the same way we would require the father / mother.

Why does the surgeon have to have the "medicine" applied to him first in this case? Simple: it's not FUCKING MEDICINE. Almost nobody chooses to get circumcised, and when they do, it's because they're switching religions, or because they have a medical problem. Well, babies don't HAVE religion. And we're not talking about ones who have medical problems. So yeah, if a doctor is going to do a ritualistic mutilation, he needs to have gone through it twice to make sure he (or she, I guess) understands it.

Anything else would be either completely unethical, or intentionally blinding oneself to the ethical problems of such an operation.
